Text:
merci!


"La JetĂŠe, the legendary science-fiction film about time and memory after a nuclear apocalypse, was released in 1964 and is considered by many critics to be among the greatest experimental films ever made. (It provided the basis for the recent Terry Gilliam film 12 Monkeys.) Chris Marker, who is the undisputed master of the film essay, composed this post-apocalyptic story almost entirely of black-and-white still photographs. The story concerns an experiment in recovering and changing the past through the action of memory, yet the film can be read as a poem dominated by a single moving image, which in its context becomes one of the supreme moments in the history of film."

http://mitpress.mit.edu/catalog/item/default.asp?ttype=2&tid=4947

http://mitpress.mit.edu/images/products/books/0942299671-f30.jpg
Idiotic, tricky, vaine and caricatural. Just a basis for a hollywood blockbuster: there is nothing to praise in being an experimental merchandise.
Warning: This movie brings no joy for morons. Nothing for blind people. If you want to see "blockbusters" - go to your local cinema with your stupid friends! Good luck :)
